Article.ArticleTitle: Synergistic analysis of atmospheric pollutants NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> based on land use regression models: a case study of the Yangtze River Delta, China.

AbstractText: Air pollution is considered one of the greatest threats to human health. This study combines a land use regression (LUR) model with satellite measurements and a distributed-lagged non-linear model (DLNM). It aims to predict high-resolution ground-level concentrations of nitrogen dioxide (NO<sub>2</sub>) and particulate matter 2.5 (PM<sub>2.5</sub>) in the Yangtze River Delta (YRD) and reveal the mechanisms of influence between NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> and precursors and meteorological factors. Results showed that the annual average NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> in the YRD urban agglomeration 2019 were 39.5 µg/m<sup>3</sup> and 37.5 µg/m<sup>3</sup>, respectively. The seasonal variation of NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> showed winter > spring > autumn > summer. There is a compelling and complex relationship between NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>. Predictors indicate that latitude (Y), surface pressure (P), ozone (O<sub>3</sub>), carbon monoxide (CO), aerosol optical depth (AOD), residential, and rangeland have positive impacts on NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>. In contrast, temperature (T), precipitation (PRE), and industrial trees hurt NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub>. DLNM model results show that NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> had significant associations with the included precursors and meteorological elements, with lagged and non-linear effects observed. Satellite data could help significantly increase the accuracy of LUR models; the R<sup>2</sup> of tenfold cross-validation was enhanced by 0.18-0.22. In 2019, PM<sub>2.5</sub> will be the dominant pollutant in the YRD, and NO<sub>2</sub> showed a high value in the central and eastern parts of the YRD. High concentrations of NO<sub>2</sub> and PM<sub>2.5</sub> are present in 86% of the YRD, meaning that residents will have difficulty avoiding exposure to these two high pollution levels.
